translated: Connected Discourses With Sāriputta 1🔽1. The Long Discourses on the Ganges
Linked Discourses The Ganges River The Eastern Direction, Etc.
At Sāvatthī.
There the Blessed One said this:
“Monks, there are these four right efforts.
What four?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anuppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ anuppādāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati.🔽Uppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pahānāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati.🔽Anuppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ uppādāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu anuppannānam pāpakānam akusalānam dhammānam anuppādāya chandam janeti vāyamati vīriyam ārabhati cittam paggaṇhāti padahati  uppannānam pāpakānam akusalānam dhammānam pahānāya chandam janeti vāyamati vīriyam ārabhati cittam paggaṇhāti padahati  anuppannānam kusalānam dhammānam uppādāya chandam janeti vāyamati vīriyam ārabhati cittam paggaṇhāti padahati
translated: There is the case where a monk generates desire, endeavors, arouses persistence, upholds & exerts his intent for the sake of the non-arising of evil, unskillful qualities that have not yet arisen.🔽He generates desire, endeavors, arouses persistence, upholds & exerts his intent for the sake of the abandoning of evil, unskillful qualities that have arisen.🔽He generates desire, endeavors, arouses persistence, upholds & exerts his intent for the sake of the arising of skillful qualities that have not yet arisen.

original: Uppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati.
analyzed: uppannānam kusalānam dhammānam ṭhitiyāḥ asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandam janeti vāyamati vīriyam ārabhati cittam paggaṇhāti padahati
translated: He generates desire, endeavors, arouses persistence, upholds & exerts his intent for the maintenance, non-confusion, increase, plenitude, development, & culmination of skillful qualities that have arisen.

analyzed: ime kho bhikkhave cattāraḥ sammappadhānā ti
translated: These are the four right strivings.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gaṅgā nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā;
analyzed: sā iyyathā api bhikkhave gaṅgā nadī pācīna ninnā pācīna poṇā pācīna pabbhārā
translated: “Just as the Ganges flows to the east, slopes to the east, inclines to the east, and tends to the east,

original: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāro sammappadhāne bhāvento cattāro sammappadhāne bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro.
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave bhikkhu cattāraḥ sammappadhāne bhāvento cattāraḥ sammappadhāne bahulīkarontaḥ nibbāna ninnaḥ hoti nibbāna poṇaḥ nibbāna pabbhāro
translated: so the bhikkhu who develops and cultivates the four right strivings slants, slopes, and inclines to Nibbana.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāro sammappadhāne bhāvento cattāro sammappadhāne bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu cattāraḥ sammappadhāne bhāvento cattāraḥ sammappadhāne bahulīkarontaḥ nibbāna ninnaḥ hoti nibbāna poṇaḥ nibbāna pabbhāro
translated: And how does a bhikkhu develop and cultivate the four right strivings so that he slants, slopes, and inclines to Nibbana?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anuppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ anuppādāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu anuppannānam pāpakānam akusalānam dhammānam anuppādāya chandam janeti vāyamati vīriyam ārabhati cittam paggaṇhāti padahati
translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu arouses desire to abandon unwholesome states that have arisen; he makes an effort, arouses energy, applies his mind, and strives.

original: Uppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pahānāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati.
analyzed: uppannānam pāpakānam akusalānam dhammānam pahānāya chandam janeti vāyamati vīriyam ārabhati cittam paggaṇhāti padahati
translated: He arouses desire to relinquish unwholesome states that have not yet arisen; he makes an effort, arouses energy, applies his mind, and strives.

original: Anuppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ uppādāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati.
analyzed: anuppannānam kusalānam dhammānam uppādāya chandam janeti vāyamati vīriyam ārabhati cittam paggaṇhāti padahati
translated: He generates desire for the arising of unarisen wholesome qualities. He makes an effort, arouses energy, applies his mind, and strives.

original: Uppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati.
analyzed: uppannānam kusalānam dhammānam ṭhitiyāḥ asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandam janeti vāyamati vīriyam ārabhati cittam paggaṇhāti padahati
translated: He generates desire for the continuance, non-disappearance, increase, plenitude, development, and fulfillment of arisen wholesome qualities. He makes an effort, arouses energy, applies his mind, and strives.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāro sammappadhāne bhāvento cattāro sammappadhāne bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro”ti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu cattāraḥ sammappadhāne bhāvento cattāraḥ sammappadhāne bahulīkarontaḥ nibbāna ninnaḥ hoti nibbāna poṇaḥ nibbāna pabbhāro ti
translated: It’s in this way, monks, that a monk, by developing and cultivating the four right efforts, inclines toward extinguishment, tends toward extinguishment, and heads toward extinguishment.”
The twelfth.

analyzed: gaṅgāpeyyāla vaggaḥ paṭhamaḥ  sammappadhāna sayuttassa gaṅgāpeyyālī sammappadhāna vasena vitthāretabbā
translated: The first sub-chapter on the Ganges is finished.
(The sub-chapter on the Ganges in the Saṁyutta Nikāya should be expanded in detail according to the right efforts.)🔽The summary:
Six inclining to the east,
and six inclining to the ocean;
These two sixes make twelve,
and that’s how the sub-chapter is called.
Saṁyutta Nikāya 55.1🔽The Chapter with Appamāda
The Chapter on Appamāda
(The chapter on diligence should be expanded according to the method of the chapter on right efforts.)
The summary:
The Realized One, the state, the peak,
the root, the essence, the rainy season,
the king, the moon and sun,
the cloth: the tenth term.
Saṃyutta Nikāya 47.1
The Chapter with Balakaraṇīya🔽The Discussion of What Should Be Done with Energy, etc.

original: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci balakaraṇīyā kammantā kayiranti, sabbe te pathaviṁ nissāya pathaviyaṁ patiṭṭhāya evamete balakaraṇīyā kammantā kayiranti;🔽evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya cattāro sammappadhāne bhāveti, cattāro sammappadhāne bahulīkaroti.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave ye keci bala karaṇīyā kammantā kayiranti sabbe te pathavim nissāya pathaviyam patiṭṭhāya evam ete bala karaṇīyā kammantā kayiranti  evam eva kho bhikkhave bhikkhu sīlam nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya cattāraḥ sammappadhāne bhāveti cattāraḥ sammappadhāne bahulīkaroti
translated: “Bhikkhus, whatever kinds of work requiring strength are done, all are done by depending on and relying on the earth.🔽In the same way, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu, depending on virtue, relying on virtue, develops and cultivates the four right strivings …

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya cattāro sammappadhāne bhāveti, cattāro sammappadhāne bahulīkaroti?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu sīlam nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya cattāraḥ sammappadhāne bhāveti cattāraḥ sammappadhāne bahulīkaroti
translated: And how, bhikkhus, does a bhikkhu, depending on virtue, relying on virtue, develop and cultivate the four right strivings?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anuppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ anuppādāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati …pe…
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu anuppannānam pāpakānam akusalānam dhammānam anuppādāya chandam janeti vāyamati vīriyam ārabhati cittam paggaṇhāti padahati pe
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu generates desire for the nonarising of unarisen evil unwholesome states…

original: uppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati.
analyzed: uppannānam kusalānam dhammānam ṭhitiyāḥ asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandam janeti vāyamati vīriyam ārabhati cittam paggaṇhāti padahati
translated: and for the continuance, non-disappearance, increase, plenitude, development, and fulfilment by development of arisen wholesome states.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya cattāro sammappadhāne bhāveti, cattāro sammappadhāne bahulīkarotī”ti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu sīlam nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya cattāraḥ sammappadhāne bhāveti cattāraḥ sammappadhāne bahulīkaroti iti
translated: It is in this way, bhikkhus, that a bhikkhu develops and cultivates the four right strivings.”

analyzed: evam bala karaṇīya vaggaḥ sammappadhāna vasena vitthāretabbaḥ  dvādasama  balakaraṇīya vaggo tatiyaḥ
translated: (The chapter on the kinds of work to be done should be expanded as in the chapter on the right strivings.)🔽The twelfth chapter on the kinds of work to be done is finished.
The third sub-chapter on the kinds of work to be done is finished.🔽The summary:
Strength, seed, and elephant,
tree, and pot, and potter;
Sky, and two on clouds,

analyzed: nāvā āgantukā nadī iti  sayutta nikāya  esanā vagga
translated: ship, and newcomer, and river.
The Connected Discourses with Esanā, etc.🔽The Chapter with Esanā, etc.🔽Ten on Searching, etc.
“Monks, there are these three searches.
What three?

analyzed: kāma īsanā bhava īsanā brahmacariya īsanā
translated: The search for sensuality, the search for becoming, the search for a holy life.
These are the three searches.

original: Imāsaṁ kho, bhikkhave, tissannaṁ esanānaṁ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya cattāro sammappadhānā bhāvetabbā.
analyzed: imāsam kho bhikkhave tissannam esanānam abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya cattāro sammappadhānāḥ bhāvetabbā
translated: “The four right strivings should be developed for direct knowledge of these three searches, for full understanding of them, for their utter destruction, for their abandoning.
What four?

There is the case where an uninstructed run-of-the-mill person—wandering & transmigrating in samsara, running & roaming on—has not seen the noble ones, or if he has seen the noble ones, he has not become familiar with their Dhamma; he has not seen a trainee, or if he has seen a trainee, he has not become familiar with their Dhamma.🔽Unfamiliar with the Dhamma of trainees, he is unfamiliar with the four ways of attending to mindfulness.🔽Unfamiliar with the four ways of attending to mindfulness, he is unfamiliar with the four right exertions.🔽Unfamiliar with the four right exertions, he is unfamiliar with the four bases of power.🔽Unfamiliar with the four bases of power, he is unfamiliar with the five faculties.🔽Unfamiliar with the five faculties, he is unfamiliar with the five strengths.🔽Unfamiliar with the five strengths, he is unfamiliar with the seven factors for awakening.🔽Unfamiliar with the seven factors for awakening, he is unfamiliar with the noble eightfold path.

original: uppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati.
analyzed: uppannānam kusalānam dhammānam ṭhitiyāḥ asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandam janeti vāyamati vīriyam ārabhati cittam paggaṇhāti padahati
translated: Unfamiliar with the noble eightfold path, he is unfamiliar with stress, its origination, its cessation, and the path of practice leading to its cessation.🔽Unfamiliar with these four noble truths, he is called an uninstructed run-of-the-mill person.

original: Imāsaṁ kho, bhikkhave, tissannaṁ esanānaṁ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya ime cattāro sammappadhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
analyzed: imāsam kho bhikkhave tissannam esanānam abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya ime cattāro sammappadhānā bhāvetabbā ti
translated: “The four right strivings should be developed for direct knowledge of these three searches, for full understanding of them, for their utter destruction, for their abandoning.”
(To be elaborated in detail.)
The tenth.
The fourth sub-chapter on searches is finished.🔽The summary:
Searches, performance, taints,
and becoming, and three kinds of stress,
The defilements, the stains, and the impurities,

analyzed: vedanā taṇhā tasinā ca ati  sayutta nikāya
translated: The feelings, craving, and the one who craves.
The Connected Discourses with Māluṅkyaputta, Thus have I heard.
The Salayatana Book🔽The Floods, Etc.
“Bhikkhus, there are these five higher fetters.
What five?

analyzed: rūpa rāgaḥ a rūpa rāgaḥ mānaḥ uddhacca avijjā
translated: Lust for form, lust for the formless, conceit , restlessness, and ignorance.

analyzed: imāni kho bhikkhave pañca uddhambhāgiyāni sayojanāni
translated: These, bhikkhus, are the five higher fetters.

original: Imesaṁ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṁ uddhambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya cattāro sammappadhānā bhāvetabbā.
analyzed: imesam kho bhikkhave pañcannam uddhambhāgiyānam sayojanānam abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya cattāro sammappadhānāḥ bhāvetabbā
translated: “For the full understanding of these five higher fetters, these four establishments of mindfulness should be developed.

analyzed: katame cattāro  idha bhikkhave bhikkhu anuppannānam pe
translated: What four?🔽Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu dwells contemplating the body as a body, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world.🔽He dwells contemplating feelings as feelings, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world.

original: uppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati.
analyzed: uppannānam kusalānam dhammānam ṭhitiyāḥ asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandam janeti vāyamati vīriyam ārabhati cittam paggaṇhāti padahati
translated: He dwells contemplating mind as mind, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world.🔽He dwells contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world.

original: Imesaṁ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṁ uddhambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya ime cattāro sammappadhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
analyzed: imesam kho bhikkhave pañcannam uddhambhāgiyānam sayojanānam abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya ime cattāro sammappadhānā bhāvetabbā ati
translated: “These four right efforts should be developed for the direct knowledge of these five higher fetters, for the full understanding of them, for their utter destruction, for their abandoning. ”
(To be expanded as above.)
The tenth.
The fifth chapter on the flood is finished.🔽The summary:
Flood, yoke, and clinging,
knots, and latent tendency;
Sensual qualities, hindrances,
and the aggregates, higher and lower.
The fifth chapter on right efforts is finished.
